blurb:
I am a seventh year PhD Candidate at the UC Berkeley School of Information co-advised by Jenna Burrell and Joshua Blumenstock. To inform the design of more responsible tech and tech policy, I use qualitative methods to understand the perspectives and experiences of impacted communities, and storytelling to influence the design of technical systems and the policies that surround their use.

My work integrates the perspectives of people with lived expertise alongside people with domain expertise (e.g., data scientists, policymaker, privacy scholars). I have conducted empirical studies in rural villages in Togo, rural ranching communities in the United States, and with people experiencing homelessness in the Bay Area.

At UC Berkeley, I am affiliated with the Global Policy Lab, AI Policy Hub, and Algorithmic Fairness and Opacity Group.

Prior to graduate school, I received my B.A. summa cum laude in Sociology from NYU. Advised by Deirdre Royster and Ruth Horowitz, my award-winning honorâ€™s thesis explored racial inequalities in the US criminal justice system.

My interest in digital tech and tech policy crystalized during my time working at a tech start-up and later at a plaintiff's employment law firm where I came to see how technology -- like laws -- could have disparate impact at scale.
